name: 2,6-di-t-butylphenol
Reason: To predict the melting point of 2,6-di-t-butylphenol, consider the functional groups in comparison to phenol, which has a melting point around 41°C. The t-butyl groups are bulky and provide steric hindrance which may disrupt the crystal lattice of the solid, generally lowering the melting point. The presence of two t-butyl groups further enhances this effect. The hydroxyl group (OH) forms hydrogen bonds, which typically increases the melting point, but the effect of the two bulky t-butyl groups is expected to dominate. For each t-butyl group, estimate the decrease in melting point to be around -12°C due to steric hindrance.
Test (Predicted reason):
The base structure for the prediction is benzene, which has a melting point of 5.5 degrees Celsius. The presence of two t-butyl groups (each consisting of a methyl group attached to a carbon atom) increases the melting point due to the increase in molecular weight and van der Waals forces. Each t-butyl group can be estimated to increase the melting point by approximately 20 degrees Celsius. The hydroxyl group (OH) is capable of forming hydrogen bonds, which significantly increases the melting point. The effect of the hydroxyl group can be estimated to be an increase of 40 degrees Celsius. The overall predicted increase from the functional groups is 20 (for each t-butyl group) + 40 (for the hydroxyl group) = 60 degrees Celsius.
